awd_titl_txt: Problem Solving Through Practice: Identifying Common Student Struggles in Solving Complex Biology Problems and Developing Tools to Drive Improvement
awd_abstract_narration:
Developing the ability to solve complex problems is a key challenge in STEM education.   Faculty frequently struggle to understand and help students master this skill, thus there is a need to explore and characterize how students engage in this skill and to determine whether problem-solving errors are primarily based on a lack of content or science skills knowledge, or on a misunderstanding about how to approach problem-solving.  This project will combine an exploration of what students are thinking as they solve problems with analysis of their performance on the same questions.  The project will also measure students' ability to reflect on how they solve problems, as well as determine whether student perception of the difficulty of a problem affects their ability to solve it.  A better understanding of how students think about solving a problem, and the errors that they make as they solve problems, will then serve as a basis for developing strategies and practice tools to improve students' problem-solving skills.

This project has two major objectives: 1) to systematically examine and compare students' cognitive processes in solving complex problems that are either content-focused or skills-focused and 2) to develop multiple kinds of validated problem-solving practice tools.  The project approaches understanding students' problem-solving processes by combining a detailed qualitative exploration of their cognitive reasoning with a quantitative analysis of how specific kinds of guidance may assist in their process.  Additionally, students' ability to regulate their thinking process (i.e. metacognition), as well as their perception of the mental effort required to solve problems, will be measured and related to problem-solving ability.   A better understanding of students' patterns of thinking and the errors they make will then serve as a foundation to independently test guidance in three areas - content, skills, and problem-solving processes.  The utility of combining and repeating this guidance can be tested, along with the contribution of mental effort and metacognition.  A detailed regression model will be built using the quantitative data collected to determine whether guidance improves performance.  This project will also provide detailed insight into student thinking while problem-solving, and will relate these patterns to performance and improvement.  Ultimately, the project will deliver these insights along with successful tools for helping students improve their problem-solving ability.  Although this project is centered on solving problems in biology and life science, learning how to solve problems has long-term benefits for all college students, therefore these findings are likely to be broadly applicable to educators and students in a variety of STEM disciplines.

por.por_cntn:
The science skills of designing and interpreting experiments, constructing arguments, and solving complex problems have been repeatedly called out as critical for undergraduate biology students to master. Yet each of these skills remains elusive to many students, particularly when integrating and evaluating multiple pieces of information is required. In this project, we explored two main areas: how students worked together in groups during a lab course to interpret experimental data, and how students individually solved problems in a genetics course. 

For group work, we established a set of codes describing 15 unique behaviors and used these to characterize student interactions. The most common behavior seen in student dialogue was analyzing data, followed by recalling information and repeating ideas. Although students cooperated with one another by exchanging information, they less frequently fully collaborated to explain their conclusions by exchanging reasoning. Within this context, students working in groups generally chose to take on specific roles during discussions and focused their attention on data analysis rather than constructing logical reasoning chains to explain their conclusions. To help students interact more productively, it may be helpful to describe productive group roles and let students practice taking on different roles, in addition to practicing how to fully support their claims and observations with reasoning.  

For genetics problem solving, we explored student success in solving genetics problems in four genetics content areas using sets of three consecutive questions for each content area. First we compared student's initial success in problem solving, and then determined whether content-focused hints helped students who had originally answered incorrectly. We found that content hints helped these students solve additional content-matched problems: students who improved following a hint typically used the hint content to accurately solve a problem. Students who did not improve upon receipt of the content hint demonstrated a variety of content-specific errors and omissions. We also collected the written step-by-step procedures individuals used to solve these problems, and developed a set of codes to describe each cognitive and metacognitive process. We used  these codes to describe over 1,800 student and 149 expert answers.  We found that students used some processes differently depending on the content of the question, but reasoning was consistently predictive of successful problem solving across all content areas. The metacognitive processes of planning and checking were more common in expert answers than student answers, but when students used these processes, they also predicted success.

In summary, we suggest that instructors not only emphasize key pieces of challenging content when teaching, but also consistently demonstrate possible problem-solving strategies, provide many opportunities for students to practice thinking about how to solve problems, and encourage students to explain to themselves and others why each of their steps makes sense.  These strategies, applicable to nearly any scientific domain, can help students learn how to use reasoning, and how to improve their approaches to solving challenging problems.
